Thanks for the help.

I am a newbie to Java/JUnit. I am going to begin by examining the suggestion
in Friday, January 20, 2006 1:41 PM about setUp/tearDown.

"rarely the best one"

It all depend on how you define "best".

If I am running tests on my PC and don't have a lot of time to delve into
the memory problem, why not add that 1 GB of memory to the PC and meet the
deliverable date ?

If this is an exercise to learn the technology, then I would investigate
setUp/tearDown, lazy loading and so on.


  -----Original Message-----
  From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of J.
B. Rainsberger
  Sent: Saturday, January 21, 2006 3:48 PM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [junit] running out of memory


  Robert Lucente wrote:
  > Googled and found http://www.w3.org/DOM/Test/Documents/DOMTSBuild.html.
  >
  > The above states, "If you get a out of memory error (very likely if you
  > build the DOM Level 3 Core tests)". It then recommends "set
  > ANT_OPTS=-Xmx512M". Request that people share how they solved their "out
of
  > memory" issue.
  >
  > Humm. This does belong in JUnit ? Perhaps this is a generic Java
question ?

  Allocating more memory is one way to work around an OutOfMemoryError,
  but it's rarely the only solution, and if it's not the only solution,
  it's rarely the best one.

  ...and yes, this is a generic Java solution to a generic Java question.
  Another solution is to look for ways to use less memory, such as lazily
  instantiating objects and letting them be collected as garbage as soon
  as possible.
  --
